life and marriage - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The European Social Survey (ESS) is a biennial multi-country survey covering over 30 nations.<br> <br> The project is funded jointly by the European Commission, the European Science Foundation, academic funding bodies and National Science Foundations in each participating country, and is designed and carried out to exceptionally high standards. The project is directed by a Central Co-ordinating Team led by Roger Jowell (Rounds 1 to 5) and Rory Fitzgerald (Round 6) at the Centre for Comparative Social Surveys, City University, London.<br> <br> The questionnaire includes two main sections, each consisting of approximately 120 items; a 'core' module which will remain relatively constant from round to round, plus two or more 'rotating' modules, repeated at intervals. The core module aims to monitor change and continuity in a wide range of social variables, including media use, social and public trust, political interest and participation, socio-political orientations, governance and efficacy, moral, political and social values, social exclusion, national, ethnic and religious allegiances, well-being, health and security, human values, demographics and socio-economics.<br> <br> <b>Accessing ESS Data</b><br> Data from rounds 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the ESS are now available via the Norwegian Social Science Data Service.<br> <br> Users will need to register with the service in order to access ESS data. Further details about this and other aspects of the project may be found on the <a href="http://ess.nsd.uib.no/" title="European Social Survey">European Social Survey</a> web pages.  In addition, ESS rounds 1 to 5 are available using the <a href="http://ess.nsd.uib.no/downloadwizard/index.html" title ="ESS Cumulative Data Wizard">ESS Cumulative Data Wizard</a>, where users can customise their own subsets of data in different formats.<br> <br> For the eleventh edition (May 2014), new editions of the main data and documentation for Round 4 (2008) and Round 5 (2010) have been published.  The new release includes the publication of post-stratification weights in the integrated files for ESS4 and ESS5, as well as corrected design weights for Israel, Slovakia (ESS4 and ESS5) and Turkey (ESS 4).<br> <br> This upgrade release is the beginning of a process of upgrading all published rounds to include post-stratification weights in all ESS resources. This process will be completed by mid-December 2014.<br> <br> A new Guide to weighting of ESS data is available from <a href="http://www.europeansocialsurvey.org/docs/methodology/ESS_weighting_data_1.pdf" title="Guide to weighting of ESS data">Guide to weighting of ESS data</a>  <br> <br> Please note that the ESS Cumulative Data Wizard and ESS Multi-level Data are not included in the current upgrade for round 4 and round 5.<br> <br> In addition Round 6 (2012) data and documentation are now available for countries Albania, France, Italy, Lithuania and Ukraine. <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>In edition to the core questionnaire, a number of rotating modules are completed at each round: <ul><li>Round 1 - immigration; citizenship, involvement and democracy</li><li>Round 2 - health and care seeking; economic morality; family, work and well-being</li><li> Round 3 - timing of life; personal and social well-being</li><li>Round 4 - welfare attitudes in a changing Europe; experiences and expressions of ageism</li><li>Round 5 - work, family and well-being (also in round 2); trust in criminal justice</li><li>Round 6 - Europeans' understandings and evaluations of democracy; personal and social well-being (partial repeat of a module from round 3)</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate>Round 1 - September 2002 to August 2003<br>Round 2 - August 2004 to December 2005<br>Round 3 - August 2006 to May 2007<br>Round 4 - August 2008 to May 2009<br/>Round 5 - September 2010 to July 2011<br/>Round 6 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd August 2012 to May 2013</collDate>         <nation>Austria</nation>         <nation>Belgium</nation>         <nation>Bulgaria</nation>         <nation>Croatia</nation>         <nation>Cyprus</nation>         <nation>Czech Republic</nation>         <nation>Denmark</nation>         <nation>Estonia</nation>         <nation>Finland</nation>         <nation>France</nation>         <nation>Germany (October 1990-)</nation>         <nation>Greece</nation>         <nation>Hungary</nation>         <nation>Iceland</nation>         <nation>Ireland</nation>         <nation>Israel</nation>         <nation>Italy</nation>         <nation>Kosovo</nation>         <nation>Latvia</nation>         <nation>Lithuania</nation>         <nation>Luxembourg</nation>         <nation>Netherlands</nation>         <nation>Norway</nation>         <nation>Poland</nation>         <nation>Portugal</nation>         <nation>Romania</nation>         <nation>Russia</nation>         <nation>Slovakia</nation>         <nation>Slovenia</nation>         <nation>Spain</nation>         <nation>Sweden</nation>         <nation>Switzerland</nation>         <nation>Turkey</nation>         <nation>Ukraine</nation>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>Countries</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>No information recorded</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>Cross-national; National</universe>         <universe>Persons aged 15 years and over resident within private households in 35 countries, during 2002-2012.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>biennial waves are planned</timeMeth>         <sampProc>Random (probability) samples with comparable estimates based on full coverage of the eligible residential populations aged 15 years and over in participating countries. See documentation for individual countries for details</sampProc>         <deviat>Round 1 - 42,359 (all countries)<br>Round 2 - 47,537 (all countries)<br>Round 3 - 43,000 (all countries)<br>Round 4 - 56,752  (all countries)<br>Round 5 - 52,458 (27 countries)<br/>Round 6 - 46,257 (24 countries)</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>See documentation for individual countries</weight>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>These data are available from a service other than UK Data Service - Norwegian Social Science Data Service - see <a href=http://ess.nsd.uib.no/>http://ess.nsd.uib.no/</a></accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Third party access conditions apply</specPerm>         <restrctn>Users will need to register with the Norwegian Social Science Data Service in order to access ESS data.
